title: Mississippi Has Invested Millions of Dollars to Save Its Oysters. They’re Disappearing Anyway.

last_post.content:
Here's a perfect example of a critical issue getting unnecessarily bifurcated between state and private management. Oyster restoration on the Mississippi coast is not going very well. Should it be privatized or kept as a state program?

Neither. It's a common property, you need a common property regime.

But since you don't have a commons, all you get is a tragedy.

https://talkingpointsmemo.com/news/mississippi-has-invested-millions-of-dollars-to-save-its-oysters-theyre-disappearing-anyway

Rituals of Childhood

https://kieranhealy.org/blog/archives/2019/08/03/rituals-of-childhood/

From last week, 7(!!!) years ago...
💥 🤩🫠

HI-PERF CLOJURESCRIPT THI.NG + WEBGL was one of many 3-day intensive workshops taught in our large kitchen in North London in 2015/16. Home cooked lunches, freshly baked biscuits, super chill atmo... Functional programming, DIY Synth, baremetal STM32, dataviz, linked data, graph databases, 3D graphics, game dev... We covered a lot of topics and had people from 11 countries attenting. Have to find a way to re-animate those somehow!

Realtime invite demo:
https://demo.thi.ng/ws-ldn-5/

Workshop report:
https://github.com/thi-ng/blog/blob/main/2016/20160502-hiperf-clojurescript.md

Related (from another WebGL workshop a couple of months later):

Racing game prototype using generated torus knots as tracks/levels:

https://demo.thi.ng/sjo/
(steer w/ mouse/touch, click to accelerate)

Project source (using #Clojure/#ClojureScript version of thi.ng/geom):

https://github.com/thi-ng/demos/tree/master/ws-ldn-8/day2/ex04/src/ex04

it's called GPT-4 because they've finally reached stage 4 of Simulacra and Simulation

> The fourth stage is pure simulacrum, in which the simulacrum has no relationship to any reality whatsoever. Here, signs merely reflect other signs and any claim to reality on the part of images or signs is only of the order of other such claims. This is a regime of total equivalency, where cultural products need no longer even pretend to be real in a naïve sense, because the experiences of consumers' lives are so predominantly artificial that even claims to reality are expected to be phrased in artificial, "hyperreal" terms. Any naïve pretension to reality as such is perceived as bereft of critical self-awareness, and thus as oversentimental.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulacra_and_Simulation#Stages

Upgraded my iPhone to iOS 16.4 to get Safari 16.4... and now I can receive web push notifications!

Managed to get one to work using https://simple-push-demo.vercel.app - frustratingly you have to add that page to your home screen (and then find it in the sea of icons) to enable the feature

That site does give instructions for using "curl" to send a notification through Apple's server, and it absolutely worked for me just now

"organized groups of young people have swept through... looking for weapons left under car seats or in unlocked center consoles or glove compartments. Their work is occasionally made easier by motorists who advertise their right to bear arms with car window stickers promoting favored gun brands, or that declare 'molon labe' — a defiant message from ancient Sparta, which roughly translates as 'come and take them.'

Increasingly, thieves are doing just that."

https://nyti.ms/3K8dTcT

title: The Texas Observer  1955-01-10: Vol 46 Iss 39 : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive

last_post.content: On the front page of one of its early issues: "Library Screens Books by Author's Politics" (on the San Antonio Public Library, in the January 10, 1955 issue): https://archive.org/details/sim_texas-observer_1955-01-10_46_39

The Texas Observer is ceasing publication, per several members of its board: https://www.texastribune.org/2023/03/26/texas-observer-shutting-down/ But the editor in chief said on Twitter it wasn't yet definite: https://twitter.com/gabrielarana/status/1640403951286730753

Its website looks to have archived issues back to 1954. I do not know what will happen to it, but Internet Archive also has open microfilm scans of most issues through 1961 (& later issues available for CDL, which I assume they'll have to deactivate shortly.) Copyright & issue info: https://onlinebooks.library.upenn.edu/webbin/cinfo/txobserver

title: Scaling Expert Language Models with Unsupervised Domain Discovery

last_post.content:
RT @johnjnay@twitter.com

Scaling Expert LLMs

-Cluster corpus into domains
-Train separate expert LLM on each cluster
-Combine in a sparse ensemble for inference

-Outperforms dense baselines on multiple corpora &
tasks
-Specializing "experts" to meaningful clusters is key

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2303.14177

🐦🔗: https://twitter.com/johnjnay/status/1640167659697209347

title: Remembering Alex Hay, the Maker of Toolbox Pro, During Automation April

last_post.content:
The Apple and iOS community lost one of the truly good ones recently.

Alex Hay, the developer of Toolbox Pro for Shortcuts, passed away last Saturday after a battle with cancer. He was 36.

The news left me devastated. With his family's blessing, we've decided to dedicate @AutomationApril to his memory. We'll be making donations to two cancer charities in his name; we encourage those who were fans of his work to do the same.

Alex was pure talent. We'll miss you.

https://www.macstories.net/stories/remembering-alex-hay-the-maker-of-toolbox-pro-during-automation-april/

#TypeScript 5.0 has a new compiler flag "verbatimModuleSyntax" which supersedes the now deprecated "importsNotUsedAsValues" and changes how type-only imports are being treated[1]. TypeScript catches most (not all!) of these occurrences as bugs, and after reviewing imports all 4000(!)+ resulting JavaScript files over the weekend (and finding & fixing another dozen or so cases), I just pushed new releases of all 179 #ThingUmbrella packages[2], now compatible with TS5.0! 🎉

One other (somewhat related) still outstanding issue to address soon is the new TC39-compatible decorator handling/behavior... I already tried updating these semi-successfully, but then deferred the work again when I realized that I'll first have to do a lot more reading & experimenting with this new setup (esp. related to mixins). The changes are quite major... Anyhow, steady progress, small steps, more often...

Happy Coding! :)

[1] https://devblogs.microsoft.com/typescript/announcing-typescript-5-0/#breaking-changes-and-deprecations

[2] https://thi.ng/umbrella

The English /s/ is "darker" at syllable coda than at syllable onset. The coda /s/ has lower peak frequency and lower amplitude in the 4-14 kHz interval than onset /s/. https://doi.org/10.1121/2.0001725

I'm less sanguine about LLMs than I was in December when I said they're essentially "asking a supercomputer to get really good at mansplaining."

I really encourage folks to check out this paper on some of GPT4's capabilities.
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2303.12712.pdf

Some of this is undoubtedly overstated. And none of this disputes the very real concerns about bias, misuse, and disinformation.

But look at some of these examples (pics attached). It's hard to reconcile with "word prediction on steroids."

title: Font optical sizing bug in Safari 16

last_post.content:
@Richr

The bug you described in this post: https://clagnut.com/blog/2423/ is fixed in Safari 16.4.
> Fixed `font-optical-sizing: auto` having no effect in Safari 16.

The problem with your user agent sniffing suggestion is that now it delivers your code to the fixed browser, since it matches `"isSafari16"`.

piping Scheme code from Bash to GNU IMP to batch convert a bunch of images from EXR (linear RGB float32) to PNG (8-bit sRGB)

```
#!/bin/bash
(
cat <<EOF
(define (exr2png in_filename out_filename)
(let* (
(image (car (gimp-file-load RUN-NONINTERACTIVE in_filename in_filename)))
(drawable (car (gimp-image-get-active-layer image)))
)
(gimp-image-convert-precision image PRECISION-U8-GAMMA)
(gimp-file-save RUN-NONINTERACTIVE image drawable out_filename out_filename)
(gimp-image-delete image)
)
)
EOF
for i in "$@"
do
echo "(exr2png \"${i}\" \"${i}.png\")"
done
echo "(gimp-quit 0)"
) |
gimp -i -c -b -
```

based on https://superuser.com/a/1558320 (an actually useful answer about using gnu imp, not the highest rated answer on this question about "how do I with gnu imp" which was "don't use gnu imp"...)

I'm not using ImageMagick because colorspace issues, even so I need to adjust gamma by ~1.15 to make it match the rest of the video rendered in a different way, so something still isn't quite right

title: US teens say they have new proof for 2,000-year-old mathematical theorem

last_post.content:
Two New Orleans high school seniors who say they have proven Pythagoras’s theorem by using trigonometry – which academics for two millennia have thought to be impossible – are being encouraged to submit their work to a peer-reviewed journal.
